results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film shows the Malins family in a montage of holidays and events in Victoria spanning several years from 1946 to the 1950s (not in precise chronological order). Highlights include a visit to Melbourne Zoo, trips to the beach along the Great Ocean Road and to Phillip Island, as well as trips to the snow at Lake Mountain. Malins frequently captured road signs of their travel destinations, including Anglesea, Lorne, Wye River and Cowes. Other moments captured include children’s birthday parties, horse riding and children at school (possibly Koonung Heights Primary School in Mont Albert North, 1954–1993).

The film also features footage of an historic gathering at the Shrine of Remembrance on the occasion of Field Marshal Bernard Law Montgomery’s visit to Melbourne in 1947.

Selected highlights (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:02:00 (upside down footage) caged orangutan at Zoo eating an ice cream
00:00:15:00 entrance to Melbourne Zoo
00:00:20:00 visitor hands food to a white-cheeked gibbon through cage fence
00:00:29:00 George, Sybil, Helen and John picnic on lawn, with the Taggart family
00:00:45:00 children ride the open-carriage train, ‘Zoo Spirit of Progress’ written on side of driver’s car (a reference to Victorian Railways premier express train from Melbourne to Albury)
00:01:07:00 children riding on an Indian Elephant
00:01:15:00 horse performing tricks for audience, balancing on a see-saw, riding and bucking in the arena with a baboon (possibly a hamadryas baboon) on back
00:01:40:00 George, Sybil, Helen and John with Mabel Malins (Nana) having a picnic with fire next to river, great shots of family members eating and smiling, at Healesville Sanctuary
00:02:40:00 Children play in yard. One boy wearing an ‘indian’ costume rides a tricycle; another boy rides a rocking horse; two girls push prams with dolls. Christmas morning at Rathmines Road, Hawthorn.
00:03:20:00 children and mother in caravan trailer, portable radio, bicycle and a 1940s Chevrolet Utility vehicle (Ute)
00:03:48:00 road sign ‘Anglesea – please slow down’
00:04:09:00 ‘Great Ocean Road’ Memorial Arch
00:04:25:00 road sign ‘Lorne – please slow down’
00:04:28:00 children walking in water and climbing on rocks at the beach
00:05:02:00 Sybil and girl standing next to road sign ‘Wye River’ at bridge
00:05:11:00 boy playing with toy boat in water
00:05:17:00 group of children paddling a yellow inflatable dinghy
00:05:51:00 John holding a small fish that he caught
00:05:59:00 gathering of families, playing games on beach
00:06:29:00 two children in bath, Helen and John
00:07:00:00 family, including Mabel Malins, celebrating Helen’s sixth birthday with cake at dining table
00:07:25:00 family in snow with sled, having a snowball fight at Lake Mountain
00:08:35:00 Helen and John at horse-riding school on country road. A man and a boy pass by standing on the back of a flatbed ute.
00:08:58:00 children ride in a horse drawn cart with a crop harvest (possibly corn)
00:09:07:00 group of nurses surround new born baby, Ruth, as she leaves hospital. Ethel Taggart briefly pictured.
00:09:17:00 people riding horses across country road
00:09:35:00 baby (Ruth) amused by family members at Whitehorse Road, Balwyn
00:10:36:00 baby hops and slides along the floor
00:10:55:00 family exiting St Mark’s Church Camberwell in formal clothing, after Ruth’s chistening; priest holding baby
00:11:41:00 John and Helen walking Ruth (toddler) in harness at Doncaster Road; John wearing leg braces
00:12:11:00 children riding on carousel at San Remo
00:12:39:00 John pushing Ruth in swing; John wearing leg calipers
00:12:56:00 John presented with the dux award at a school, Balwyn Primary School
00:13:13:00 family playing tennis-like game at Wye River beach; Mabs, Ruth and Janet playing with sand
00:13:45:00 in a lounge room, next to a fireplace, George and Sybil and their two daughters throw beach balls to each other (217 Doncaster Road with Bill Gladstone, Ruth and Janet)
00:14:20:00 intertitle card “Wake’y Wake’y”: a day in the life of Ruth and Janet
00:15:33:00 Ruth and Janet holding toys, a baby doll and a plush dog
00:15:45:00 intertitle card “Breakfast”
00:16:10:00 intertitle card “Off to School”: Sybil waving goodbye to her daughters who leave the home with their ports (small briefcases)
00:16:26:00 the girls running through a playground
00:16:39:00 intertitle card “Assembly”: outdoor gathering of students standing in line formations, hand on heart
00:17:16:00 students march into classrooms; crates of glass milk bottles stacked outside one classroom
00:17:46:00 Australian flag blowing in the wind
00:17:54:00 intertitle cards “Forestry Commission’s Lecture”; “Arbor Day at Koonung School 1956”
00:18:10:00 intertitle card “Mr. Godfrey – Our Headmaster”
00:18:26:00 intertitle card “Frances, Joanne and Janet Planting a Tree”
00:18:51:00 adults and children watch as children plant trees (excellent example of 1950s fashion)
00:19:00:00 classroom puppet show, children performing a song and dance for parents
00:20:10:00 girl writing in book at a wooden desk; the desks have ink bottle holders
00:20:30:00 group of children dancing in formation outside
00:21:50:00 Janet’s 6th birthday party: hildren wearing homemade party hats with blowers, sit around a cake and snack spread
00:22:17:00 Nan, Ruth and Janet at the Nobbies Phillip Island, then riding wooden belly boards at Wye River with Dora Kennedy and son John
00:22:58:00 girl and dog climbing on rocks at beach
00:23:03:00 young man fishing from rocks at beach
00:23:11:00 family takes shelter under rocks
00:23:23:00 family riding inflatable dinghy in the Yarra River, Warrandyte
00:24:11:00 koala sitting in and climbing a tree
00:24:23:00 road sign ‘Cowes – please slow down’
00:24:28:00 crossing the wooden bridge to Phillip Island
00:25:21:00 men playing golf in Apollo Bay next to beach, with boats and distant landscape in background
00:25:30:00 putting on golf green
00:25:58:00 “C.O.R.” written on a weathervane
00:26:02:00 Pontiac driving on Great Ocean Road, with wide shot of hillside coastline
00:26:51:00 car bogged on a snow covered road, people attempt to release it
00:27:02:00 children having a snowball fight
00:27:13:00 people make a snowman, dressed with a hat, scarf and buttons
00:27:38:00 riding sleds down a snow covered hill
00:28:32:00 wide shot of tree covered mountains and valleys
00:29:06:00 large group of children and adults riding horses in country location
00:29:59:00 large gathering of people at Shrine of Remembrance; soldier marches across the front of shrine
00:30:22:00 soldiers wearing slouch hats marching toward the shrine; the reflecting pool (removed in the early 1950s) is partially shown with Melbourne skyline in distance
00:30:37:00 Highly decorated men in uniform gather. Man wearing black beret is Field Marshal Bernard Law Montgomery, 1st Viscount Montgomery of Alamein. His presence places this footage in 1947. Surrounded by enormous crowd of people, including police officers wearing a black bobby helmet.
00:31:10:00 family in Chevrolet Ute with caravan trailer
00:31:28:00 family at beach dressed in skirts made of newspaper, bows and flowers in hair; men wearing stuffed brassieres perform a dance
00:32:05:00 people catching waves, riding wooden belly boards
00:32:34:00 Australian National Airways plane (possibly a Douglas DC-4), ‘Bungana’ written on exterior of cockpit. Propellers start to spin, plane moves.
00:33:03:00 Ansett Airways plane (possibly a Douglas DC-3), turns on tarmac
00:33:06:00 man on horse in residential area, Bulleen Riding School
00:33:10:00 fancy dress party at 217 Doncaster Road; children in costumes (yellow bird and nurse) in yard at “Heath’s home”
00:33:22:00 large gathering of children and women at Wattle Park with picnic baskets (Janet’s kindergarten)

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 4 and Reel 5] [excerpts]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

The collection is filmed on 16mm and 9.5mm film and the films can sometimes be a bit damaged and shaky.

This 9.5mm example is from excerpts of Reels 4 and 5, showing scenes of Jack’s family and friends enjoying their scrambler motor bikes in muddy conditions at Korweinguboora, near Ballarat, Victoria. A group of friends are then shown travelling around the Victorian countryside on motorcycles (motorbikes). Motorcycles have been filmed from a vehicle travelling alongside. The bike riders gather for the camera at the ‘Atlantic Garage’ possibly in Ballarat and then head off for a ride down a dusty country road.

results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 12]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

The majority of this film is comprised of scenes from the Athletic Carnival, showing a great snapshot of sport and fashions of the period.

It also features scenes from the Cheshunt State School in the King Valley, showing the schoolchildren learning about river erosion. This section of film was possibly filmed as part of a documentary made by members of the Wangaratta Camera Club called ‘Treasures of the King’, which was made to show the need for a dam across the King River.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 a parade with a marching band
00:01:00:00 Union Jack flying
00:02:00:00 bagpipes and highland dancing
00:02:52:00 Cheshunt State School, a small weatherboard building
00:02:59:00 schoolchildren sitting on the grass
00:03:10:00 a teacher in cat eye glasses speaking to the children in front of the school
00:03:29:00 two men with cameras taking photographs of the children in their lesson
00:04:02:00 the children making a dam, learning about river erosion
00:04:51:00 title card ‘Wangaratta Athletic Carnival 1958’
00:06:37:00 sprinters set off
00:07:06:00 man with a starter pistol
00:08:09:00 woman in a pink polka dot dress wearing a hat made out of newspaper
00:08:31:00 boy in a tartan cap eating a Peters brand ice cream
00:08:46:00 sign ‘W.B. Richardson Stand’
00:10:23:00 truck sprinkles the track with water from a tank; a handwritten sign on the tank reads ‘No training while watering’
00:10:36:00 a man shows off to the camera, flipping a cigarette into his mouth while smoking
00:11:58:00 firemen demonstration; the teams have the name of their town emblazoned on their shirts, including Myrtleford, Bright and Wangaratta
00:13:56:00 a stylish couple, both dressed in white, the woman wearing a ruffled lace halterneck

results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 11]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

This film shows scenes of a motor racing circuit. Ted films the cars from alongside the track, showing the dusty, mud-splattered action, as well as close-ups of the drivers, mechanics and race cars. The action throughout gives an insightful and exciting look at the sport.

A feature is a spectacular image of a burnt out car driving straight through a billboard set on fire.

results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

This film takes place at the the motor racing circuit in Tarrawingee, Victoria, which was used by the North Eastern Car Club between 1957 and 1965. It includes footage of motorcycle and motorcar races, as well as the people in the crowd out for a Sunday event, providing a great snapshot of the townspeople and recreational activities of the period.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 poster ‘Motor Racing at the new Tarrawingee Circuit’
00:01:11:00 cars taking off around the circuit
00:02:52:00 dust flying as cars careen around the bend
00:03:04:00 young people sitting on a fence, wearing the full skirts and cardigans of 1950s style
00:03:25:00 spectators watching
00:03:50:00 man holding chequered flag across the track
00:04:51:00 the children’s train ride
00:05:43:00 two men in boiler suits push a race car off
00:06:16:00 a driver gets out of a Volkswagon Beetle in the ‘Pits’
00:07:40:00 a Fordson Major tractor
00:08:19:00 a red lorry being led by a tractor, sprinkling the race track with water from a tank
00:09:27:00 view from interior of a car driving the race track
00:10:43:00 stylish women lounging on the grass
00:11:24:00 cars arriving at the Finish line

results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

In this film, titled ‘Just Roaming’, Ted tells the story of a road trip through Victoria. The Parsons travel through Mount Hotham and Myrtleford, down to Melbourne and then back through Bairnsdale and Paynesville on the south coast.

A feature is the footage of the Gliding Club of Victoria, including female pilots, and historic buildings in Melbourne such as the Shrine of Remembrance and Ormond College at the University of Melbourne. There are beautiful scenes of the Victorian countryside throughout.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title cards ‘E.J. Parsons Presents’, ‘Just Roaming’
00:00:11:00 a 1950s car leaves the driveway of a brick house and drives down a country road
00:00:35:00 flooded roads and paddocks, uprooted trees in the river
00:01:30:00 a visit to the Hume Dam (formerly known as the Hume Weir) including scenes of Lake Hume
00:02:55:00 man with binoculars, looking out to snow covered mountains
00:03:28:00 two women and a man playing with snowballs
00:04:27:00 a man and woman wade through the snow; woman playfully flashing her underwear to the camera
00:04:50:00 snowy countryside
00:06:33:00 the Hotham Heights Hotel in Mount Hotham, with guests on the balcony looking out over the railings
00:06:51:00 bleached white gum trees and yellow buttercups
00:07:33:00 beautiful views across the mountain ranges
00:08:59:00 a clock tower
00:09:18:00 road sign ‘Myrtleford Please Slow Down’
00:09:27:00 a helicoptor landing in a field, followed by footage of gliders taking off and landing
00:10:27:00 logo ‘Gliding Club of Vict.’ on a wing
00:10:33:00 two young men seated in a glider, smiling and waving at the camera
00:10:59:00 a yellow glider taking off
00:11:19:00 young woman in a glider
00:11:57:00 gardens
00:13:14:00 bridge over the Yarra River, Melbourne, with a church spire in the background
00:13:33:00 the Shrine of Remembrance, Melbourne
00:14:18:00 boys in a red row boat on the Yarra
00:14:25:00 Ormond College, University of Melbourne
00:14:38:00 flowers
00:16:11:00 feeding the seagulls at the beach
00:17:16:00 farm paddocks
00:17:28:00 scenic shot of three people on a rocky outcrop
00:17:43:00 sign for ‘Bairnsdale Please Slow Down’ followed by scenes in the country town
00:18:22:00 a unicycle mounted on a white brick wall
00:18:29:00 the Technical School, Bairnsdale
00:20:34:00 road sign ‘Paynesville Please Slow Down’
00:20:55:00 two women walking along the beach
00:21:32:00 view from a boat on the river
00:22:52:00 boat named ‘Krunulla’
00:24:05:00 poplar and pine trees
00:27:09:00 title card ‘Springtime’ followed by scenery in country and footage of farm animals

results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 6]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

This film consists of a range of scenes filmed throughout the 1950s on various holidays. It features travels to Melbourne for the Royal Tour, a trip to Beechworth for a town parade and snippets of travels to Queensland and New South Wales.

A highlight of the film is footage of the Royal Tour in 1954, showing crowds of people in the streets of Melbourne and Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip driving past.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 ships in Port Melbourne with flags flying
00:00:30:00 crowds gathered at the railing
00:00:39:00 the ‘Princess of Tasmania’
00:01:11:00 large crowds of people in the city street, running and waving as the cavalcade passes by
00:02:21:00 panning across Melbourne city buildings and bridge across the Yarra River including advertising for ‘Bushells’ tea on a building
00:02:42:00 Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip pass by in an open car, waving at the crowd
00:02:59:00 crowds at the Sidney Myer Music Bowl in the King’s Domain, Melbourne
00:03:46:00 sign reads ‘The Sir Colin Mackenzie Sanctuary’, Healesville, followed by scenes of wildlife in the sanctuary
00:06:40:00 a visit to a farmhouse, views of horses in the country paddocks and women horseriding
00:07:10:00 a foal feeding from a mare
00:07:44:00 a woman in a printed sun dress holding a skittish foal by the bridle
00:08:17:00 Parliament House, Melbourne
00:08:18:00 flooded river with fallen trees after a storm
00:08:40:00 scenes of countryside
00:09:10:00 a family on a rocky outcrop surrounded by gum trees, pointing to the view
00:09:13:00 woman feeding peacocks
00:09:34:00 seaside scenes, sailboat on the water
00:10:20:00 cherry trees
00:10:41:00 garden with a sprinkler
00:11:00:00 parade through town centre of Beechworth, with people dressed in the fashion of the gold rush era
00:11:17:00 woman dancing in emerald green dress and bonnet, showing her white bloomers
00:11:24:00 man with wheelbarrow and sign reading ‘Melbourne to Beechworth or bust’
00:11:41:00 parade crowds with advertising signs and shopfronts behind: ‘The Dolphin Coffee Parlour’ and ‘Peters Ice Cream’
00:11:46:00 people in parade dressed as gold prospectors in stereotypical Chinese outfits
00:12:02:00 a group of people wearing a dragon costume
00:12:16:00 a child in a blackface costume
00:12:57:00 lovely printed dresses on women in the crowd
00:13:00:00 members of the parade dancing in costume
00:13:38:00 a Shetland pony harnessed to a small carriage with young girl seated inside
00:13:59:00 close-ups of flowers, butterflies and bees
00:14:38:00 beach scenes including people wearing printed bathers
00:14:48:00 Galapagos turtle
00:15:11:00 dolphins playing with balls in the Pet Porpoise Pool, Coffs Harbour
00:15:28:00 toll booths on the Sydney Harbour Bridge, with sign reading ‘Lane changing prohibited’
00:15:32:00 driving across the Sydney Harbour Bridge
00:16:08:00 bulldozer clearing a path on a country property

This film consists of a range of scenes filmed throughout the 1950s on various holidays. It features travels to Melbourne for the Royal Tour, a trip to Beechworth for a town parade and snippets of travels to Queensland and New South Wales.

A highlight of the film is footage of the Royal Tour in 1954, showing crowds of people in the streets of Melbourne and Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip driving past.

results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

This film takes place on the Jubilee Golf Course in Wangaratta, in its original location on a property on Yarrawonga Road. The club was established in 1935 and in 1963 moved to its present location on Wangandary Road. Ted was President of the Jubilee Golf Club from 1939 to 1955, as shown by a plaque in a cigarette box he received. The film features scenes of the locals playing games of golf and the 1956 Grand Tournament, and features some great examples of 1950s sporting fashion.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 sign ‘Jubilee Golf Club’
00:00:14:00 scenes of the golf course and golfers teeing off
00:01:28:00 women chatting at the weatherboard club building
00:01:46:00 four female golfers cross the course with their golf clubs, wearing pleated skirts and cardigans
00:02:07:00 view up the hill to golfers amongst the trees
00:02:42:00 a group of golfers under a large tree; two women tee off while a group of men look on
00:03:24:00 views across the course
00:05:35:00 stylish golfer in brown check skirt and pink cardigan
00:06:27:00 two men in woollen flat caps
00:06:44:00 golfers gathered outside the golf club, a modest weatherboard building
00:06:53:00 poster for ‘Grand Tournament Wangaratta Jubilee Golf Club’
00:07:49:00 several men tee off in front of the club house as crowd applauds
00:08:36:00 championship board
00:09:02:00 presentation table set up with flowers, six glasses on a silver platter and wooden cigarette box
00:09:13:00 focus on cigarette box with interior sign ‘Presented to E.J. Parsons’
00:09:25:00 more views of golfers on the course

results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

In this film, Ted captures a trip to Queensland and New South Wales. The film features scenes of holidaying in Queensland, touring around Surfers Paradise, Brisbane, the Sunshine Coast and Coffs Harbour, before travelling down the East Coast from Sydney to Eden and Lakes Entrance. The film includes memorable scenes such as a show of aqua ballet and water ski stunts in Surfers Paradise, dolphins in the Pet Porpoise Pool in Coffs Harbour, historic buildings in Brisbane and fruit farms on the Sunshine Coast.

Of particular interest is Lennon’s Hotel in Broadbeach, which was one of the earliest hotels in Surfers Paradise. At the time, there were few buildings around and the hotel was surrounded by stretches of sand dunes and unsealed roads. It would become the site of the current ‘Oasis Shopping Centre’.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:04:00 title ‘Queensland Gold Coast 1961’ followed by a sequence where travel brochures are tossed over the title card for hotels and destinations including Brampton Island and Surfers Paradise
00:00:23:00 looking toward Lennon’s Hotel, a very colourful, modern 1960s style roadside hotel
00:00:50:00 sign ‘Welcome to Surfers Paradise’
00:00:55:00 scenes around the pool at the hotel including women sunbaking in bikinis
00:01:32:00 sign ‘KR Darling Downs Bacon’ above a shopping plaza
00:02:37:00 the bridge to Chevron Island in Queensland
00:02:54:00 sign in dry grassland for ‘Shopping Centre Here’
00:03:24:00 handpainted sign for ‘Water Ski Revue and Aqua Ballet’ in Surfers Paradise Gardens
00:03:48:00 scenes of spectators on grassy slopes and the performers on the waterskiing show
00:04:41:00 a woman with a full head of hair ‘curlers’ which was a not uncommon look in the 1960s
00:04:51:00 a woman in costume for the aqua ballet, wearing a blue feathered tutu
00:05:04:00 various waterskiing stunts entertain the appreciative crowd
00:06:22:00 Mount Coot-Tha in Brisbane, a mountain with panoramic views over the city
00:08:14:00 traffic on a main road lined with palm trees
00:09:38:00 view of Brisbane City Hall
00:10:00:00 view of the Queensland National Art Gallery in its former premises on Gregory Terrace where it operated from 1931 to 1974
00:10:25:00 sign for the ‘Lone Pine Koala Sanctuary estd. 1927’
00:10:37:00 a koala riding on the back of a German Shepherd dog, hugging its neck
00:11:35:00 view of the grand sandstone Forgan Smith Building at the University of Queensland
00:13:26:00 exterior of the Buderim Ginger Growers Co-Op’s original ‘Merrybud’ factory, west of Mooloolaba on the Sunshine Coast
00:13:48:00 fruit farms, including strawberry fields and pineapple groves
00:17:00:00 fruit pickers and workers in the cane fields
00:20:11:00 kite surfer on the river
00:20:57:00 bougainvillea and two women in the gardens
00:22:00:00 banana plants
00:22:37:00 title card ‘Caloundra’
00:22:45:00 exterior of the Reef Hotel
00:23:34:00 large ship arriving on the coast
00:24:02:00 title card ‘Coolangatta’
00:24:05:00 exterior of the Kirra Beach Hotel
00:24:39:00 the Natureland Zoological Gardens
00:28:38:00 swimming and snorkelling with 1950s examples of oxygen tanks
00:29:37:00 exterior view of the George Gilltrap’s Auto Museum with displays of early twentieth century cars and trucks
00:30:48:00 a demonstration of a 1913 fire engine with a group of firemen dressed in uniform, watched by a crowd of onlookers
00:31:50:00 men pumping the fire hose
00:33:40:00 the Pet Porpoise Pool in Coffs Harbour, a small aquarium
00:35:07:00 visitors feeding dolphins, leaping up to catch fish from people’s hands
00:37:29:00 sign for ‘Galapagos Island Giant Tortoise’ named Harry
00:38:47:00 sign for ‘The Sanctuary’ across a river
00:38:53:00 rosellas feeding
00:39:16:00 two women feeding rosellas from bowls, birds landing on their heads and arms
00:39:36:00 a toddler screaming as a kangaroo paws its head
00:40:32:00 the Terranora Lakes Country Club Estate with golf course and swimming pool
00:41:30:00 the Hornibrook Bridge, a heritage-listed bridge built by Manuel Hornibrook in the early 1930s crossing Bramble Bay
00:42:39:00 the Sydney Harbour Bridge
00:42:52:00 Macquarie Lightstation, Vaucluse, which was Australia’s first lighthouse
00:44:27:00 focused views of the Sydney Harbour Bridge, followed by views across the harbour
00:46:09:00 title card reads ‘Eden’
00:46:21:00 a campfire on the beach with a billy boiling
00:47:05:00 title card ‘Lakes Entrance’ followed by views over the estuary
00:47:51:00 fisherman pulling fish from a net on a dinghy
00:48:55:00 roadside picnic with table set up and playpen for a toddler
00:49:58:00 cooking sausages and bacon over stones
00:50:30:00 title card ‘The End’
